titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI: Monday. Drafted a Letter to Mr Rush— The weather which is warm and rainy, with my necessary occupations prevented me from attending Mrs Barlow’s funeral. At the Office Mr Ten Cate came and introduced Mr Lechleitner as his intermediate successor— The Newspapers announce, he says, he thinks truly, that a Vicomte de Quabeck is coming in his stead— Mr Lechleitner brought me a Letter of Recommendation from the Baron de Nagell; the Minister of foreign Affairs of the Netherlands. Mr G. Graham likewise called at the
Office, to inform me that he should be ready to go upon his expedition the day after to-morrow and to ask for his Instructions. R. Kemper came to ask explanations of some observations that I had made to him on Saturday— Mr Nelson thought they imported some distrust of Kemper’s character, and he knew, that he had been misrepresented to Mr Monroe by his Enemies— I told him that I knew nothing of that— My objections and observations were not to his character but to the claims which he had brought forward and was urging— Mrs Adams rode out after dinner, and I took a short walk.

2. V:30. Drafted Instructions to Mr G. Graham and sent to the Office a part of my files of Newspapers. Going to the Office I met Mr Cruft, who with his wife left the City for Alexandria— They expect to be returned early in July to Boston; I asked him to undertake the agency for my houses in Boston; chiefly for the purpose of effecting the sale of them, which he promised— My brother has requested me to relieve him from the. care of this part of my Estate— The remainder of the day I was at the Office without interruption; and the Mail only brought a few Letters requiring no immediate or special attention. After dinner I walked with Mrs Adams over the Tiber, and down to the Potowmack Bridge— She came home much fatigued.

3. V:45. Morning much wasted. At the Office Mr G. Graham came and took his final instructions. It is always embarrassing to settle the compensation for these anomalous services. In this case the President said the analogy that occurred to him as proper, was an equality with the pay of a member of Congress. Mr Graham’s expences were to be paid; and I thought the addition of five dollars a day would make that equality. The President directed me to fix it at that— He had however spoken himself of six dollars a day. Graham however seems to think it not enough. He said he had told the President that as he had intended, independent of this appointment to make a tour this Summer to the Alabama Territory, and as his expences would be paid, he should receive no other compensation; for there was no compensation in money, which would induce him to go upon such an expedition as this, at this Season of the year— I am curious to see how this pretension will end— Whether upon his return, he will quietly take his five dollars a day, and expences? Whether his expences will amount to less than three dollars a day: (to equalize his pay with that of a member of Congress) and whether his disinterested obligingness to the President, will eventuate in pretensions to better offices?— He also shewed me two Letters recommendatory of his brother John; one from Mr Madison to Mr Monroe, and the other from Mr Monroe himself on leaving the Department of State— He was to have been appointed Minister at Rio da Janeiro, on the Event of Mr Sumter’s return home; which is now to be remembered; Sumter having positively asked for his recall— But George says his brother does not like Rio Janeiro, and he thinks will not accept the appointment there— Perhaps however when the offer is made him, he may change his mind— I took a long walk with Mrs Adams, after dinner.

4. V:30. Letter to J. M. Forbes, Copenhagen. The great heat of the Sun compelled me to ride to and from my Office in the Carriage. A Mr Birckhead of Baltimore came with a Ream of Recommendations from Baltimore for his brother James Birckhead to be Consul at Rio de Janeiro. The rest of the morning I was without interruption and assiduously engaged. Walked an hour after dinner, and Mrs Adams went to Burnside’s warm Baths, to which I subscribed for the Season.

5. VI. Began drafting Instructions to G. W. Campbell for his Russian Mission from which I was soon obliged to desist at the office, I was employed all the morning in reading Mr Pinckney’s despatches since he has been in Russia— There is one paper of observations, on the project of a commercial Treaty, which is valuable, and worthy of him. He was at St. Petersburg only 13 Months, had been there only four when he wrote, asking to be recalled, and finally came away without waiting to receive his Letters of Recall; which must have reached St. Petersburg within a fortnight after his departure. He left his Son Charles Pinkney as Charge d’Affaires. Mr Cathcart came to the Office, pleading distress, which I cannot relieve, and asking an advance of money which I cannot grant. Mr. W. Taylor
arrived from his abortive agency to Haÿti— King Christophe refused to receive him without a formal recognition of his royal title. Mr Lechleitner came to say he was going on Sunday for Philadelphia. He wished for the order from the Treasury for the repayment of extra Tonnage duties on Netherland vessels may direct the repayment to be made not to the Consignees; but to the owners or Captains or their assigns. Lechleitner says that Ten Cate is very reluctant at going home, and delays too long obeying the order of his Government. Mrs. W. S. Smith dined with us— He was here after dinner, but I was walking out and did not see him— Heat oppressive.

6. IV:30.Mr William Taylor called this morning at my house, and gave me an account of his voyage to Cape Henry of Haÿti; and his failure of obtaining acceptance there— I proceeded in the draft of Instructions to G. W. Campbell, and wrote several short Letters at the Office— Thomas Hellen and Robert Buchanan dined with us. Thomas has entirely recovered from his fall into the river— Mrs Adams rode out with them this Evening— There was a very heavy Thunder Shower this Morning, and several others afterwards; but the sun came out with fiercer heat after them and the evening was quite sultry.

7. V:30. Notwithstanding the Thunder showers of yesterday, the heat of this day was excessive and occasioned a languid inactivity under which I always lose my time. Mr D. Brent called to tell me that he should be absent from the Office to-morrow. I bathed in the Potowmack about an hour before dinner; but the tide being down, it was less pleasant than the last time. Mary Hellen was confined to her bed, all day— She has a quartan fever. There was distant thunder part of this day; and in the Evening the wind came, Northeasterly and with a cooler air.

8. VI: A Mr Webster, a Clergyman of Hampton in New-Hampshire called this Morning at my house. He shewed me two Letters from other clergymen, by which it appeared that he was sent as delegate to a Presbyterian clerical Convention at Philadelphia— He told me that when he left home he had not intended to come further, but being at Philadelphia the curiosity had seized him to come to Washington; and when here, he called on me to enquire concerning W. S. and J. A. Smith, whom he had known as boys at Atkinson; having resided at Mr Peabody’s there with them; and having been very much attached to them; especially to John— He also wished to know if he could get a sight of the President’s house. I gave him the information requested, concerning the Smith’s; and asked him to call at my Office at one O’Clock, where I would endeavour to procure for him the means of seeing the President’s house. I found him at the Office when I went there, and W. Lee readily went with him to shew him the house. Lee, who has made a large purchase of the City Lands invited me to go with him some evening & look over them— He says the man of whom he purchased has still nineteen Squares for sale— Dr Blake and young Carroll were at the Office, to recommend a Mr Tabbs, formerly of Maryland, for the appointment of District Attorney for the Indiana district, instead of Dr Blake’s son, who has resigned upon being appointed a judge, by the Governor of the State— Mr Brent was absent from the Office— The day cool and pleasant. Mary-Hellen better but does not leave her chamber. In the Evening I walked with Mrs Adams to the Capitol Hill, and we paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Crawford.

9. V:30. Continued the draft of Instructions to G. W. Campbell in the course of which I find myself expatiating upon subjects not strictly within the scope of the paper I am writing. It grows too desultory and too minute. I nevertheless suffer my pen to run on; and shall probably leave most of the pruning to the President. I called at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office, and enquired if the Instructions to the Collectors of the Customs for refunding the extra Tonnage-duties on Vessels of the Netherlands, had issued— He said they had, and gave me a printed copy of the circular— He appeared to be embarrassed what to do with a certain prize to a South American privateer which has come into Newport Rhode-Island, and upon which the Spanish Consul has presented himself as claimant for the original owners— I had no interruption at the Office, but wasted the morning in reading L. Harris’s Letters to the Department, while he was Charge d’Affaires in Russia. We spent the Evening at the French Minister Hyde de Neuville’s— A small musical party— Mr Bagot spoke to me of certain publications in the Newspapers, mentioning the execution by sentences of Court Martial under the orders of General Jackson, of two Englishmen, named Arbuthnot and Ambrister, taken with the Seminole Indians in this War. These publications say that the Evidence against them proved the greatest perfidy on
the part of the British Government— Mr Bagot was very much hurt by this charge of perfidy, for which he said there was not the slightest foundation— I told him that I had seen none of Genl. Jackson’s despatches giving an account of these transactions. That I knew not from whom or whence the newspaper publication came— That I was very sorry that any white men, and especially Englishmen had been found with those Seminoles— That I did not know how long the British Government had continued or when they had closed their connection with the Seminoles formed by Coll. Nicholls during the late war— But Nicholls had made what he called a Treaty Offensive and defensive with them after the Peace— That I had by orders from this Government remonstrated against it, both verbally and in writing, to Lord Bathurst and Lord Castlereagh, who had verbally disavowed Nicholls’s Treaty; but never in writing, which I had much regretted— He renewed the assurance that the charge of perfidy against his Government was entirely without foundation— I played part of a game of Chess with Commodore Decatur— Home about eleven.

10. VI:15. Wasted some time in sorting and arranging the files of Newspapers, that I am sending to the Office. Went there between twelve and one. Reading Harris’s despatches. Wrote a draft of a Letter to R. Rush on the case of the Brig William and Mary. This Evening a young Mr Jackson came to me with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Dana the Senator from Connecticut. Jackson has an earnest desire to go as the Secretary of Legation to Russia, with Mr Campbell— As Mr Campbell wants a Secretary who can speak and write French, he told Jackson that he would receive any person whom I should recommend as thus qualified. Jackson sent me therefore sometime ago a specimen of his French writing; and now came to shew me how he could speak it— He told me Mrs Campbell expected her husband here to morrow— Mrs Adams took an evening ride, and I walked round the Capitol Hill.

11. V:30. Finished at length the first draft of General Instructions for G. W. Campbell— He arrived in the City last Evening. Mrs Adams was very unwell all the morning, but recovered before dinner— I was without interruption at the Office, but wrote nothing— After dinner I rode with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen to a farm of G. Johnson’s beyond Kalorama, and which is for sale. The road to it is almost inaccessible— From the heat of the weather I can neither read nor write after dinner.

12. IV:15. Bathed in the Potowmack, immediately after rising— The river is within a few yards of two Miles from my house, and I was two hours engaged upon this operation— Made the draft of a second Letter of Instructions to G. W. Campbell. The part relating chiefly to his personal concerns— It brought me to past one O’Clock before I left my house to go to the Office. Mr G. W. Campbell came there, and had a long Conversation with me concerning his Mission and objects connected with it, particularly the choice of a Secretary of Legation. There are a multitude of candidates, who want the place, but the candidate wanted by the place can scarcely be found— Mr Campbell who has no choice between them, leaves the responsibility of the choice to the President. He says he did not make the Offer to young Astor, but perhaps the President did— I mentioned to him John S. Smith, for whom he expressed no predilection; and F. C. Gray who pleased him better. He finally thought it would be best to postpone fixing upon the person till after the President’s return— Mr Hay sent me a certificate from Judge Cranch, addressed to the President, enclosing an affidavit from the Marshal of the District, and from the Jailor; that they consider the present condition of the Gaol, as not sufficiently secure for the safe keeping of the Prisoners— The Marshal wanted a Military guard, which just before the President went away was for some days supplied by order of the War Department— I therefore sent the Papers to the War Office, and this day Major Van der Venter the Chief Clerk of that Department came and made several objections, to furnishing a guard. He said they had not troops enough here to keep a constant guard, day and Night, unless it should be taken alternately with the Marines of the Navy Department— That he had applied to
Mr Homans, who declined furnishing the necessary quota of Marines, to keep a constant guard; considering the custody of the Prison, as a thing for which the civil authority was responsable, and for which it would be improper to call permanently on the military power. It would be liable to public animadversion and was a very ungracious service upon which to employ the soldiers and officers— I therefore determined to leave the subject as it is until the President’s return, for his Consideration— We had a heavy thunder shower, but which left the atmosphere very little cooler, or fresher than it was before. I took after dinner my solitary walk; and Mrs Adams rode out with Mary Hellen.

13. VI: Drafted a third Letter of Instructions to G. W. Campbell, on subjects not properly connected with his Mission, but in which resort will be had to his agency— The ratified Treaty with Sweden is to be committed to his charge; and the affair of J. L. Harris— The President determined that he should no longer continue as Consul of the United States at St Petersburg— But to avoid the harshness of an absolute removal, he assented to the request of L. Harris that he should advise his nephew to resign and come home. As the Consul however may be slow in taking such advice, the President directed me to give Mr Campbell a Letter to J. L. Harris, revoking his Consular Commission; to be delivered to him only in case of necessity. I also drew a Letter of Introduction for Mr Campbell to Balfour, Ellah and Rainals at Elseneur— I called on Mr Pleasonton for a paper relating to L. Harris’s Accounts— I found Mr Wirt, the Attorney General, in Mr Pleasonton’s old chambers, and Pleasonton himself in those lately vacated by the Branch Bank— At the Office, I was engaged in the examination of an account of a Printer, for printing the Laws of the last Session of Congress— He contracted for the printing as the lowest bidder, and now demands forty per Cent more than he contracted for— Thomas Hellen and Robert Buchanan dined with us— There was another thunder-shower this day, without refreshing the air— Mrs Adams took the boys home after dinner, and I walked round the Capitol Hill— Mary Hellen had a slight return of her intermitting fever this Morning, and Mrs Adams was also unwell.

14. V: A very sultry and oppressive Night. I bathed in the Potowmack near the Bridge, and at half past five found the tide had turned about an hour. Dr Hunt was here, and Cardelli. I wasted so much of the day in reading newspapers, that I had barely enough left to bring up my journal. There was another thunder-shower, after which the air became cooler, though without clearing off. Mrs Boyd sent her son Thomas here, who dined with us. Mrs Adams took him home after dinner. I walked a mile down the avenue.

15. V:30. Besides the usual waste of time which robs me of two thirds of every morning, I had this day a man who came with subscription papers for a map of the World, and a map of the United States by John Melish who detained me a full hour— De Kraefft the Printer wrote me that he wanted to give me personally explanations to account for his exorbitant demand for printing the Laws of the last Session of Congress— I sent him word to call upon me at my house at ten to-morrow Morning— Mr Bagot came to the office, with a proclamation from the Lieutenant Governor of the Province of New-Brunswick, suspending their Plaister Law, till the pleasure of the Prince Regent concerning it can be known— But he had no copy of the prohibitory Laws of New Brunswick, which is thus suspended— So I requested him to write me a note, enclosing the proclamation, and stating that it is equivalent to a repeal of the prohibitory Law— He asked me for answers to his notes concerning the Bahama’s and Turks Island, and concerning Warrington’s capture of the Brio de Mar— There was a young man named Burrows, who brought a Letter of recommendation from Governor Wolcott of Connecticut— He wants to be employed as a Messenger to go to Europe; or to obtain a passage in the Guerriere so that he may travel over the ground of Buonaparte, from Moscow to Paris. His manners are gawky, genteel and his deportment assuming and self-sufficient— He also asked of me a personal introduction to Mr Davis the Innkeeper— He says he has a personal acquaintance, and will wait for his return to apply for a passage in the Guerriere. I walked after dinner and Mrs Adams took a warm bath.

16. IV:15. Began the day by bathing in the Potowmack. Then wrote a short Letter, and idled away the rest of the morning till noon— De Kraefft the Printer was here, and attempted to explain his non-fulfilment
of his contract for printing, for the department. He said the contract had not been fulfilled on the part of the department; and complained that the copy for printing the Laws had not been furnished him in time. As I was going to the Office I called at Mr Crawford’s to ascertain the state of our foreign tonnage duties. Major Vander Venter was with him, and had Letters from the South, purporting that General Jackson had taken Pensacola by Storm, and with considerable bloodshed. Crawford thinks Jackson intends to withdraw from investigation of his conduct, by resigning— I met Mr Bagot who went with me, to the Office, and gave me a copy of the Plaister Law of New-Brunswick. Mr G. W. Campbell came to the Office, and had much Conversation with me, on his proposed Mission to Russia— He inclines much to take Mr F. C. Gray as his Secretary of Legation— After dinner I walked with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen over the Tyber to the River— Mr. and Madame Hyde de Neuville spent an hour here this Evening, but I had retired to bed before they came.

17. V: It is scarcely possible to recollect how the Morning wastes away, and how I find it gone, and nothing done. On going to the Office, I found the President had returned from his Southern tour, and I immediately went over to his house. Found Mr Crawford and Mr G. W. Campbell with him. Mr Campbell was afterwards at my office— Mr Cutts likewise called at the Office, on Affairs of private concernment. I left with the President the Draft of general instructions to Mr Campbell— Mr Barlow came this morning to my house, to speak of the settlement of the Accounts of his uncle who died while he was Minister of the United States in France in the year 1812. He claims Credits which the accountant does not consider himself authorised to allow. Mrs Adams went and spent the Evening at Mrs Middleton’s at Georgetown. Mr Burrows came to ask of me Letters of recommendation to Mr Gallatin and Mr Rush. I took a short Evening walk, and retired just after dusk to bed; but without being able to sleep, till near Midnight.

18. V:30. Change of weather, and very cool. I had a very good Morning Bath in the Potowmack with an opportunity of diving from a Raft, now near the spot. At the President’s he told me he had written to Mr. Pinkney at Baltimore requesting him to come here before Mr Campbell goes. The President hesitates appointing F. C. Gray as Secretary of Legation to Russia; though Campbell himself strongly inclines in his favour. The President spoke also of the taking of Pensacola by General Jackson, contrary to his orders, and as it is now reported, by Storm— This and other events in this Indian War, makes many difficulties for the administration. G. W. Campbell was at the Office, and was apprehensive that the President would appoint young C. Pinkney for his Secretary of Legation— W. S. Smith was at my house this Evening, and told me many particulars of the situation in which his fathers affairs were left. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s.

19. V:30. Made a draft of a Letter to Jonathan Russell at Stockholm, to be sent with the ratified Treaty with Sweden by Mr Campbell, and I took the draft with the Letters from Mr Russell, that are to be answered, to the President’s and left them with him for Consideration— The President appeared inclined to employ the young Mr Burrows, who brought a Letter of Recommendation from Governor Wolcott, to carry the Treaty from Elseneur to Stockholm. At the Office I had a visit from Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister, who came to enquire after a young Frenchman imprisoned at Cape Henry, Hayti, in whose behalf we had written to obtain his liberation. But Mr Taylor having been sent back without reception, we have ourselves no person there, who can make the representations which we had forwarded— Mr de Neuville also argued over again the question of the claim that under the Convention for the Cession of Louisiana, French vessels should pay no higher duties than English vessels— I found that the real object of this pretension is to make a claim for the sake of selling it— Mrs A passed the Evening at Mrs Frye’s— Rainy Morning, and day so cold that I resumed Winter Pantaloons— Evening walk round the Capitol-Hill.

20. V:30. Wrote a Letter to C. Hughes junr. to go by Mr Campbell. At the President’s: he has concluded to send the Treaty with Sweden, by this young Mr Burrows, to have a motive for accommodating him with a passage in the Guerriere— I had a visit from J. P. Todd, at the Office. We had Company at dinner— Mr. and Mrs Crawford, Mr and Mrs Bagot, Mr and Mrs Hyde de Neuville, Mr and Mrs. Campbell, and Messrs.Baker, Brent, Bourqueney, Hay, Hughes, Ten Cate and Todd, and in the Evening a larger party at tea; with Music. Mrs: Campbell after dinner met with an accident by spraining her foot and went home quite ill.

21. V:30. The weather has grown warm again. I received yesterday two anonymous Letters; one warning me to beware of the Ides of March, and of South-American emissaries; and the other disclosing a pretended conspiracy of another kind against me. I put them on my file, and wait to see if any Event will disclose the real motives of the writers, which are manifestly different from their apparent purport. I wrote several private Letters, and received despatches from Messrs.Gallatin and Eustis. Also a remonstrance from the Spanish Minister Onis against General Jackson’s late proceedings in Florida— In my walk before dinner I went to the mouth of the Tiber, and in the Evening accompanied Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen to Mr Thos Peter’s at Georgetown, where they took tea. We came home about ten.

22. VI:45. I sent Antoine this Morning to Tennison’s Hotel to pay the tax of 1815 and 1816. upon lots N. 19 and 20 in Square 231. which I lately purchased— They were advertised to be sold, unless the tax should be paid, on or before this day. When he got there, they could not tell him what the tax upon my two lots was, because there was an assessment of 64 dollars upon them, together with seven Squares and a house, and no proportion struck of the several parts— They therefore actually sold my two lots for fourteen dollars, which were offered by Mr John Law, who purchased them in for me; while it is impossible that my proportion of the tax should have amounted to more than one dollar. I went to Tennison’s, and there renewed the offer to pay my part of the tax, but Dr Blake, the collector, declined receiving it— I told them it was impossible they should be proceeding according to Law, and that I should not pay for the taxes of others— One of the seven Squares, belonged to S. Pleasonton— I called at his office—and gave him notice of it— At the President’s I found him intending to go in the course of a few days to Virginia, to pass the Summer— He had just received two Letters from Mr W. Pinkney; the latter of which recommended his Son Charles, for Secretary of Legation to Mr Campbell— There was a Mr King who was Secretary of Legation to Mr Pinkney— He left St. Petersburg in August last, without resigning his Office, or giving any notice of his coming away, to this Government— He was here some time last Winter, but never came to the Department, nor gave notice of his resignation. Mr Pinkney, when King left him, appointed provisionally his Son Charles; a youth scarcely of age, as his Secretary. Mr Pinkney himself left St: Petersburg in February, without waiting for his Letters of recall; although they were on the way to him from London, and must have arrived within three weeks after his departure— He left his Son there, as Chargé d’Affaires; but in his letter to me announcing this disposition requested that Charles might be relieved as soon as possible; it being by no means his desire that Charles should continue in the diplomatic career— By the time however when Mr Pinkney met the President at Annapolis, he had changed his mind, and no doubt he gave a hint there that he was willing Charles should continue a diplomatist. He now makes no scruple of asking for him the appointment of Secretary to Mr Campbell’s Legation— Campbell came to the Office, and was not very well pleased when I told him of this probable arrangement. I advised him to see the President— Young Burrows came also to the Office— I gave him Letters of Introduction to Mr Gallatin and Mr Rush, and a Passport— Coll: Kemper came with three Letters recommendatory of his character, and told me that Judge Nelson had written a long Letter in favour of his Claims to the President— These visitors again absorbed all my Office hours. I came home at five, and after dinner, walked round the Capitol Hill. I met Mr Cutts this morning, & agreed to take his Metropolis Bank Shares—1000. And this Evening I wrote to Peabody, about the tax on the Lots.

23. IV:30. Began Letters to A. Gallatin, R. Rush, and A. H. Everett, and found myself unable to proceed with either— On my way to the Office, I stopped at the Bank of the Metropolis, and gave my Note at 60 days for 11700 dollars, Mr Cutts having yesterday transferred to me a thousand Shares, on each of which 13 dollars are paid. The residue, with an advance of 12 1/2 per Cent I am to pay to Mr Cutts— At the President’s, I met Mr Campbell, and was obliged to postpone taking Instructions upon various subjects— Mr Campbell afterwards came to the Office. He had concluded not to fix upon his Secretary of Legation until he shall arrive at Boston, and have seen
F. C. Gray. Campbell has a great aversion to having Charles Pinkney, on account of his youth, and inexperience; but since W. Pinkney has asked for the place for his Son, he feels himself somewhat delicately situated, not knowing how to decline— The President agreed with him that the appointment should be postponed till he reaches Boston, but Campbell strongly intimated to me that his choice was fixed, and he should offer it to Gray— He even proposed to me to write to Gray and sound him, whether he would incline to go. I thought it best however to leave it to himself; and to take no part in the question between Gray & Pinkney. Mr Hyde de Neuville wrote me a Note asking to see me; and I received him immediately. He said the French frigate Eglantine had just arrived at New York to purchase a Cargo of flour to supply the Island of Martinique— That the deputy Collector at New York had demanded a tonnage duty of 2 1/2 dollars a ton, as upon a foreign vessel coming from a Port, where American vessels are not allowed to go and trade. The French Consul had insisted that this regulation applied only to Merchant vessels and not to ships of War; to which Mr Galston the Collector assented, but wished to have a line of Instruction from the Department— I told Mr De Neuville that meant the Treasury Department, and referred him to Mr Crawford. We had some Conversation upon the French Colonial, excluding Laws, of which I complained, and told him I should hereafter remonstrate farther. He professed to be well disposed on that subject— Two foreigners came to the Office—one a native of Smyrna, named Hiary; who came to this Country with Mina, and being without employment and in want, offered his services, as a translator from various languages— The other a Frenchman named Calamel, who applies for a portion of Tombigbee Lands. A Mr Harlan came also, applying for the Office of Consul at St. Thomas, and brought Letters of Recommendation from J. Sergeant to me; and from C. J. Ingersoll to the President— And thus passed the Office hours of another day— I took a solitary walk after dinner, Mrs Adams spent the Eve at Mrs Decatur’s.

24. V: Morning half lost, reading the Fudge family at Paris—Squibs, and fire rockets. Continued the draft of Instructions for A. H. Everett, but I find the subject enlarges as I write— At the Presidents I found Mr Crawford, and was detained an hour by his business— My own was again almost all postponed— The President has finally determined to let Mr Campbell take on with him to Boston, a blank Commission for Secretary of Legation; to be filled there with the name of F. C. Gray, or of Charles Pinkney at his option— It was near three O’Clock, when I reached the Office; and I had scarcely time to read and enter the Letters by the mail, when I was obliged to go home— Mr Yhary the man of Smyrna came again, and I promised him employment if we should have occasion for his translations. Received a multitude of despatches. The President sent to the Office, a confidential Letter to him from R. Rush, enclosing an anonymous Letter to J. A. Smith, promising most important communications of secrets, at a fair price— Rush seems more than half ready to fall into this guinea trap— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s.

25. IV:45. Instructions for Everett continued, till I was obliged to stop for want of documents which are at the Office. Going to the President’s I met Mr Anderson the Comptroller, who told me that the President had agreed to Commission Dr Blake as Register of Wills in this district in the room of a Mr Hewitt who is to be removed for intemperance. At the President’s I met Mr Crawford and was again detained much by his business— The President told me that he should leave the City to-morrow Evening or the next day, and go to his farm about fifteen Miles distant; and when the Instructions for MessrsGallatin and Rush should be prepared he would come back for a few days— But he proposed to pass the Summer between his farm, and his place at Albemarle. He seemed to manifest an aversion to reading any papers upon business. Mr Campbell was at the Office; making further enquiries relating to his Mission. He takes the Commission for a Secretary of Legation, with the name in blank on to Boston, and a Letter from me to F. C. Gray.
Mr Bagot sent me a note asking an interview, for which I appointed 3 O’Clock. He came, and said that as he was about sending a Messenger to England it would be expected that he should say something about the Execution of the two British subjects Arbuthnot and Ambrister, and the occupation of Pensacola by General Jackson. He asked if copies of the proceedings of the Court-Martials had been received— I told him they had not; nor any official account of the taking of Pensacola— I could without hesitation tell him however, that this measure was not authorized by the Government, and was unexpected. General Jackson’s despatches would no doubt disclose his motives, of which it was not possible to judge by anticipation— He said he had never for a moment believed that General Jackson had been authorised to take Pensacola— As to the case of the two men, he could not undertake to say before hand that there were no possible circumstances which would warrant their execution; he could not indeed imagine any; but the proceedings of the Court-Martial, might shew them.— As I was willing to change the subject of Conversation, I asked him if he had any late intelligence from England—particularly with regard to Spanish and South American Affairs— He had none— I said I wished that in writing to his Government he would remind Lord Castlereagh of his promise made through him Bagot, last January, to communicate to us very shortly, what the allies were doing about South-America— He said he was convinced there was no other cause for the delay than that Lord Castlereagh knew nothing further himself—that nothing further had been done. I mentioned Rioadaira’s Letter to Lord Castlereagh, and the Moscow Memoir, both of which we had received from other sources, and which he might have communicated; and I desired him to urge upon his Government the necessity of communicating freely with us, of their acts and intentions, if they expected from us a course harmonizing with theirs— I then entered at large upon the question what the allies would and what they could do— And declared the conviction that there could be no rational interference of foreign powers in that quarrel, but on the basis of the Independence of the South Americans—to which he opposed nothing as argument— He finished by requesting me to ascertain whether British vessels would under our new Navigation Act, be admitted from Bermuda?— I received several despatches from Buenos Ayres, Chili, and Spain, which I immediately sent over to the President. After dinner I took my usual walk, and Mrs Adams her usual ride— Heat overpowering.

26. IV:30. Bathed in the river, at the mouth of the Tiber, a different place from that which I have heretofore used. The distance to walk there, is about the same. A bath is a consumption of two hours of time. The walk there, the bath, and the return each taking half an hour; and then half an hour of loitering. But it is so much of the best possible bodily exercise, at the best time of the day— It is in this intensely hot weather such a luxury of enjoyment that when I rise in the morning the temptation to it is irresistible— In cool weather I feel no such inclination. To the loss of time however I should add an hour after returning, when I am idle from warmth and dissipation of Spirits. I called this morning at Mr S. H. Smith’s Office, and conversed with him concerning the tax upon my lots. He thought the proceedings of the sale last Saturday illegal; but did not see where the remedy could be found. I called also at Pleasonton’s—and he suggested that the tax might be apportioned, according to the Assessment of the City Books— At the President’s— He had concluded to go from the City this Evening, to his farm in Loudsun County, Virginia 33 Miles distant from hence; and altho the moment is very critical, and a storm is rapidly thickening he has not read many of the papers that I left with him, and he puts off every thing for a future time— After some conversation with him on the case of Captain Obed Wright, and of Mr Bagots call upon me yesterday, and on the proceedings of Genl. Jackson I left him— At the Office soon afterwards I received a Note from him saying that he had conferred with the Attorney General upon Captain Wright’s case— That Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt would call at the Department of State, when we must settle what should be done, and I must inform him of the result. They accordingly came, and after much discussion we agreed in opinion that Wright should be first tried before the circuit Court of the United States and if they should disclaim the jurisdiction, he should then be left for trial to a Militia Court Martial of the State of Georgia— As it was past five O’Clock before we came to this conclusion, Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt, declined waiting to subscribe to it as a
written opinion, and left me to draw it up, and communicate it to the President, which I did. There was a heavy thunder shower; and my Carriage came and took me home— Mr Preble came to the Office to solicit an appointment as Consul at Odessa— Kemper came but I could not see him. After dinner there came to my house a Mr Zamorana, Spanish Consul, with a huge packet of despatches from G. W. Erving; forwarded from the Spanish Minister Onis, at Bristol— There were also two Notes from Onis himself—one communicating the release of R. W. Meade, and the other asking explanations, of the article in the National Intelligencer purporting that General Jackson had taken Pensacola by Storm. Mr Erving’s packet contained only maps— Mr Zamorana requested I would send Mr Onis, a written acknowledgment of having received the despatches. Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mrs Pleasonton’s— It was so sultry and hot that I did not walk out— Retired at eight O’Clock to my bed-chamber, but from the heat could not sleep till midnight. The most oppressive Summer weather here is that which immediately follows a thunder-shower.

27. IV:30. River Bath; at the old spot, and from the raft— Lost much of the morning by the heat of the weather— Received a Letter from Mr John Law to inform me that my two Lots would be resold this Morning, as I had not paid the money for which they were bought in last Saturday. I called at the Branch and Metropolis Banks— At the Office, Mr G. W. Campbell, came to say he proposed to leave the City next Tuesday, A person, named Canes, a native of New Orleans, but generally now residing at the Havana, came to solicit the appointment of commercial agent there, with several Letters of Recommendation. I told him that the place was already occupied, but he said that Mr Stevenson had not been and would not be recognized as commercial agent by the Government at the Havanna, and that he was now in Baltimore where he arrived last week, in a passage of 7 days. Coll. Kemper came and took up an hour, going again over the old grounds of his claims— Mr Seaton came to ask for some abstract of the intelligence lately received from South America, to be published in the National Intelligencer, which he said had been recommended by the President. I gave him the Letters from J. B. Prevost to read, and the address to Captain Biddle to copy for publication— Thus were consumed the Office hours— Met my Carriage coming for me as I was returning home. Immediately after dinner a Captain Prior, who said he belonged to Quincy came to my house, with his papers— His ship has been seized at Philadelphia, for an attempt of one of his Passengers to smuggle— On the exhibition of the Papers, the Secretary of the Treasury thought further evidence necessary to disculpate Prior from connivance in the attempt to defraud the Revenue. So by the advice of the Collector at Philadelphia he has come here himself and came to me to solicit my good offices with the Secretary of the Treasury— Tom Hellen and Robert Buchanan dined here— Mrs Adams took them home this evening. The heat kept me at home.

28. IV:15.Mrs. Adams was taken ill in the Night, and continued the whole day quite unwell; with symptoms of Dysentery, and a painful cough and sore breast. Sent for Dr Hunt who came and gave her an emetic, and prescribed twenty drops of laudanum at bed time— I bathed this morning in the Potowmack from the raft nearly behind the mansion house— Kept house the remainder of the day, and the extreme heat, with anxiety for my wife’s illness made me waste it almost all in idleness; to the great sufferance of my public duties— The Sun rose clear, and scarce a cloud overshadowed his disk till he sunk in the West. It was one unclouded blaze— The Morning and Evening were calm, but the greater part of the day there was a fresh breeze first from the Northwest, and which finally died away at the North-East— From 2. till 5. P.M. Fahrenheit was at 92. rising from 74. at Sun rise, and falling only to 84. this Evening. Mr Bailey called and spent half an hours here.

29. V: Changed my bed-chamber, and slept with doors and windows open, on a hard Mattress four feet high and five feet wide. This is the only way in which I find it possible to sleep at all. I bathed this Morning at the Mouth of the Tiber— There was again a brisk North-west breeze, which sprung up soon after Sun-rise, and continued all the morning— The thermometer was however at 94. and towards Evening the breeze died away, and another very light one about South came up— The wind itself is tepid. I found myself however more able to write this morning than I was yesterday. I wrote Letters for and to Mr Campbell till one Oclock— Then called at Mr Crawford’s Office in behalf of Captain Prior— He had already given the order for the release of the Ship— Mr Crawford gave me a Letter from W. Ellery the Collector at Newport R.I. concerning a piratical vessel called the B. seized and condemned in R. Island, and an order for a noli prosequi obtained from the President, upon an indictment against the Captain. I was next at Anderson the Comptroller’s Office, to speak about the closing of A. H. Everett’s accounts; as Secretary of Legation upon the Mission to the Netherlands— He promised to send me a copy of the account, as settled at the Treasury. At my own Office. I had Major Vanderventer and Mr Homans, the chief Clerks of the War and Navy Departments, the first about the proceedings to be instituted in the case of Captain Obed Wright, concerning which the President had left a written Instruction, and upon which I must consult with Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt. Mr Homans came for directions to give Instructions to Captain M’Donough of the Frigate Guerriere, in which Mr Campbell is to embark for Russia— Mr Wichelhausen, brother of our Consul at Bremen, came with a Letter from the Senate of Bremen to the President, and one to me about the discriminating duties. And Mr A. C. Mitchell came with further Letters in behalf of W. D. Robinson— With all these visitors, and the daily mail, I had as usual not a moment for writing at the Office: from which I rode home to dinner. Nothing done after dinner, for the heat.

30. IV: Potowmack bath at the Mouth of the Tiber. Wrote the last Letter for Mr Campbell. Rode to the Treasury Office, and held a consultation with Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt, on the Commission to be issued for the trial of Captain Wright— We agreed that the Commission could not issue till after he shall have been legally apprehended and that then the Commission must go to two judges of the Supreme Court, and the judge of the District Court of Georgia— No such Commission has yet issued under the law, and I am much concerned lest by some law quibble, a flaw may be found in it, which will defeat the prosecution— At the Office W. Lee came to say he should go for New-York the day after to-morrow and to offer his services— I dined with General Mason, on his Analostan Island— Mrs Adams was unwell and sent an excuse. General and Mrs Swift,Major Vanderventer and Commodore Decatur were there. The heat continues excessive— We had a slight thunder-shower while at dinner— I found my Carriage at the ferry & came home alone about 9 O’Clock.

Day. I have risen the Month through between four and six O’Clock, and read or write till breakfast time except the mornings when I bath in the river which have been one third of the Month. Then to write my journal with a hand every day more and more shaking—and writing drafts of Letters or Instructions, or attending to visitors (Les facheux) till noon or later— Reach my Office at one or two. Read and enter the Letters by the mail— Visitors (facheux again) till five. home to dinner. After which I sometimes read the Newspapers of the day and sometimes take half an hour’s walk, but now am usually disabled by the heat, and waste the time in idleness till nine or ten.
